        "contents": "# FAQ &amp; Troubleshooting\n\nCommon questions and solutions for the DHH modpack.\n\n## Installation Issues\n\n### Q: \"Out of memory\" crash on launch\n\n**A:** Allocate more RAM to Minecraft:\n- Prism/MultiMC: Edit Instance → Settings → Java → Maximum memory allocation\n- Recommended: 4-6GB without shaders, 8GB+ with shaders\n\n### Q: Mods aren't downloading / packwiz-installer fails\n\n**A:** Check:\n1. Internet connection is working\n2. pack.toml URL is correct and accessible\n3. Java is installed and in PATH\n4. Try running packwiz-installer manually to see errors:\n   &#96;&#96;&#96;bash\n   java -jar packwiz-installer-bootstrap.jar https://YOUR_URL/pack.toml\n   &#96;&#96;&#96;\n\n### Q: NeoForge version mismatch error\n\n**A:** This pack requires exactly **NeoForge 21.11.34-beta**. Update your NeoForge installation to match.\n\n### Q: \"Mod X requires Fabric\" error\n\n**A:** This shouldn't happen as the pack includes Sinytra Connector. If it does:\n1. Verify Sinytra Connector and Forgified Fabric API are installed\n2. Check if the mod is known to be incompatible with Connector\n\n## Gameplay Issues\n\n### Q: Low FPS / poor performance\n\n**A:** Try:\n1. Lower render distance (8-12 chunks)\n2. Disable shaders or use a lighter shaderpack\n3. In Sodium settings, lower graphics quality\n4. Disable Distant Horizons if not needed\n5. Run &#96;/spark profiler&#96; to identify issues\n\n### Q: Shaders not working\n\n**A:** \n1. Press Escape → Options → Video Settings → Shader Packs\n2. Select \"Complementary Reimagined\" or your preferred shader\n3. Ensure you have enough RAM allocated (8GB+ recommended)\n\n### Q: Voice chat not working\n\n**A:** \n- **Client**: Check audio devices in Simple Voice Chat settings (V key by default)\n- **Server**: Ensure port 24454 UDP is open in firewall\n- Test with &#96;/voicechat test&#96;\n\n### Q: Waystones not appearing in world\n\n**A:** Waystones generate naturally in villages. You can also craft them. In new worlds, they will appear in newly generated chunks.\n\n### Q: Maps not saving / resetting\n\n**A:** Xaero's maps are stored per-server. If the server IP/name changes, maps may appear reset. Check &#96;.minecraft/XaeroWorldMap&#96; for saved data.\n\n## Server Issues\n\n### Q: Server won't start\n\n**A:** Common causes:",

        "contents": "# Installation Guide\n\n## Requirements\n\n- Minecraft 1.21.1 \n- ~4GB RAM allocated to Minecraft (8GB recommended with shaders)\n\n## Client Installation\n\n### Method 1: Prism Launcher / MultiMC (Recommended)\n\nThis method provides automatic updates whenever you launch the game.\n\n1. **Create a new instance**\n   - Open Prism Launcher or MultiMC\n   - Click \"Add Instance\"\n   - Select Minecraft **1.21.11**\n   - Install **NeoForge 21.11.34-beta** as the mod loader\n\n2. **Download packwiz-installer-bootstrap**\n   - Get &#96;packwiz-installer-bootstrap.jar&#96; from [GitHub Releases](https://github.com/packwiz/packwiz-installer-bootstrap/releases)\n   - Place it in your instance's &#96;.minecraft&#96; folder\n\n3. **Configure pre-launch command**\n   - Right-click your instance → Edit → Settings → Custom Commands\n   - Enable \"Custom Commands\"\n   - Set **Pre-launch command** to:\n   &#96;&#96;&#96;bash\n   \"$INST_JAVA\" -jar packwiz-installer-bootstrap.jar https://YOUR_PACK_URL/pack.toml\n   &#96;&#96;&#96;\n   &gt; Replace &#96;https://YOUR_PACK_URL/pack.toml&#96; with the actual URL where the pack is hosted.\n\n4. **Launch the game**\n   - The installer will automatically download all mods on first launch\n   - Future launches will check for updates\n\n### Method 2: Manual Installation\n\n1. Install NeoForge 21.11.34-beta for Minecraft 1.21.11\n2. Download all mod JARs from Modrinth using the links in [mods.md](mods.md)\n3. Place mods in your &#96;.minecraft/mods&#96; folder\n4. Download the shaderpack from Modrinth and place in &#96;.minecraft/shaderpacks&#96;\n\n&gt; ⚠️ Manual installation requires you to update mods yourself.\n\n## Server Installation\n\nSee [Server Setup Guide](server-setup.md) for detailed server installation instructions.\n\n### Quick Start\n\n1. Download [NeoForge server installer](https://neoforged.net/)\n2. Run: &#96;java -jar neoforge-installer.jar --installServer&#96;\n3. Use packwiz-installer to download mods:\n   &#96;&#96;&#96;bash",

        "contents": "#!/bin/bash\n# DHH Modpack Client Update Script\n# Compatible with Prism Launcher, MultiMC, and other launchers\n\nset -e\n\n# Switch to script directory (inside .minecraft)\ncd \"$(dirname \"$0\")\"\n\n# Determine Java executable\nif [ -n \"$1\" ]; then\n    JAVA_CMD=\"$1\"\nelif [ -n \"$INST_JAVA\" ]; then\n    JAVA_CMD=\"$INST_JAVA\"\nelif command -v java &amp;&gt; /dev/null; then\n    JAVA_CMD=\"java\"\nelse\n    echo \"==============================================\"\n    echo \"[ERROR] Java not found!\"\n    exit 1\nfi\n\necho \"Using Java: $JAVA_CMD\"\n\n# 1. Download bootstrapper if not present\nif [ ! -f \"packwiz-installer-bootstrap.jar\" ]; then\n    echo \"Downloading packwiz-installer-bootstrap...\"\n    curl -LO https://github.com/packwiz/packwiz-installer-bootstrap/releases/latest/download/packwiz-installer-bootstrap.jar\nfi\n\n# 2. Synchronize mods folder (Cleanup stale JARs)\necho \"Synchronizing mods folder...\"\nif [ -d \"mods\" ]; then\n    # Fetch lists of valid mods from index.toml\n    # This extract filenames from 'file = \"mods/modname.pw.toml\"' and converts to .jar\n    VALID_MODS=$(curl -s https://dhh.dobrovolskyi.xyz/index.toml | grep 'file = \"mods/' | sed -E 's/.*mods\\/(.*)\\.pw\\.toml.*/\\1.jar/' | tr '[:upper:]' '[:lower:]')\n    \n    if [ -n \"$VALID_MODS\" ]; then\n        for mod in mods/*.jar; do\n            [ -e \"$mod\" ] || continue\n            filename=$(basename \"$mod\" | tr '[:upper:]' '[:lower:]')\n            if ! echo \"$VALID_MODS\" | grep -qxw \"$filename\"; then\n                echo \"[CLEAN] Removing stale mod: $(basename \"$mod\")\"\n                rm \"$mod\"\n            fi\n        done\n    fi\nfi\n\n# 3. Run the installer\n\"$JAVA_CMD\" -jar packwiz-installer-bootstrap.jar https://dhh.dobrovolskyi.xyz/pack.toml\n\necho \"Update complete!\"",

        "contents": "# Server Setup Guide\n\nComplete guide for setting up and configuring a DHH modpack server.\n\n## Requirements\n\n- Java 21+\n- 4GB RAM minimum (8GB+ recommended)\n- Linux, Windows, or macOS\n\n## Installation\n\n### 1. Install NeoForge Server\n\n&#96;&#96;&#96;bash\n# Download NeoForge installer\nwget https://maven.neoforged.net/releases/net/neoforged/neoforge/21.11.34-beta/neoforge-21.11.34-beta-installer.jar\n\n# Install server files\njava -jar neoforge-21.11.34-beta-installer.jar --installServer\n\n# Accept EULA\necho \"eula=true\" &gt; eula.txt\n&#96;&#96;&#96;\n\n### 2. Download Mods\n\nUsing packwiz-installer (recommended):\n\n&#96;&#96;&#96;bash\n# Download packwiz-installer-bootstrap\nwget https://github.com/packwiz/packwiz-installer-bootstrap/releases/latest/download/packwiz-installer-bootstrap.jar\n\n# Install server-side mods only\njava -jar packwiz-installer-bootstrap.jar -s server https://YOUR_PACK_URL/pack.toml\n&#96;&#96;&#96;\n\n### 3. Start Server\n\n&#96;&#96;&#96;bash\njava -Xmx8G -Xms4G -jar neoforge-server.jar nogui\n&#96;&#96;&#96;\n\n## Configuration\n\n### Simple Voice Chat\n\nThe server needs a dedicated UDP port for voice chat.\n\n1. Edit &#96;config/voicechat/voicechat-server.properties&#96;:\n   &#96;&#96;&#96;properties\n   port=24454\n   bind_address=0.0.0.0\n   &#96;&#96;&#96;\n\n2. Open port 24454 UDP in your firewall:\n   &#96;&#96;&#96;bash\n   # Linux (ufw)\n   sudo ufw allow 24454/udp\n   \n   # Linux (firewalld)\n   sudo firewall-cmd --add-port=24454/udp --permanent\n   &#96;&#96;&#96;\n\n### EasyAuth (Offline Mode Authentication)\n\nEnable if running in offline mode for account protection.\n\n1. Set &#96;online-mode=false&#96; in &#96;server.properties&#96;\n2. Configure &#96;config/easyauth/config.json&#96;:\n   &#96;&#96;&#96;json\n   {\n     \"experimental\": {\n       \"enableServerSideTranslation\": true\n     },\n     \"main\": {\n       \"requirePassword\": true\n     }\n   }\n   &#96;&#96;&#96;\n\nPlayers register with &#96;/register &lt;password&gt;&#96; and login with &#96;/login &lt;password&gt;&#96;.\n\n### Ledger (Logging &amp; Rollback)\n\nLedger logs all block changes for grief protection.\n\nCommands:\n- &#96;/ledger inspect&#96; - Toggle inspect mode (click blocks to see history)\n- &#96;/ledger search&#96; - Search for actions\n- &#96;/ledger rollback&#96; - Revert changes\n- &#96;/ledger restore&#96; - Restore rolled-back changes\n\n### Chunky (Pre-generation)",

        "contents": "# - Respects side = \"client\" | \"server\" | \"both\"\n# - Hash verification for cached downloads\n# - Automatic cleanup of orphaned mods\n# - Real-time progress output (flush=True)\n&#96;&#96;&#96;\n\n### loop.sh Integration\n\nThe server's &#96;loop.sh&#96; calls the deployment script before starting:\n\n&#96;&#96;&#96;bash\npython3 deploy_modpack.py\nif [ $? -ne 0 ]; then\n    echo \"❌ DEPLOY FAILED!\"\n    # ... error handling\nfi\n# Then start NeoForge server\nbash run.sh nogui\n&#96;&#96;&#96;\n\n### Why Not packwiz-installer?\n\nThe standard &#96;packwiz-installer&#96; had issues with:\n- Not properly cleaning stale mods\n- Inconsistent handling of &#96;side&#96; metadata\n- Leaving orphaned Fabric mods after migration\n\nThe custom script ensures a 100% clean server environment.\n\n## Client Update Scripts\n\n### Directory Structure\n\n&#96;&#96;&#96;\nclient/\n├── update.bat           # Windows (Prism, MultiMC)\n├── update.sh            # Linux/macOS (Prism, MultiMC)\n└── packwiz-installer-bootstrap.jar  # Downloaded automatically\n&#96;&#96;&#96;\n\n### Windows (update.bat)\n\n&#96;&#96;&#96;batch\n@echo off\ncd /d \"%~dp0\"\n\"%~1\" -jar packwiz-installer-bootstrap.jar https://dhh.dobrovolskyi.xyz/pack.toml\n&#96;&#96;&#96;\n\n**Usage in Prism Launcher:**\n1. Copy &#96;client/&#96; folder to your instance's &#96;.minecraft/&#96;\n2. Set Pre-launch command: &#96;cmd /c \"$INST_MC_DIR/client/update.bat\" \"$INST_JAVA\"&#96;\n\n### Linux/macOS (update.sh)\n\n&#96;&#96;&#96;bash\n#!/bin/bash\ncd \"$(dirname \"$0\")\"\n\"${1:-${INST_JAVA:-java}}\" -jar packwiz-installer-bootstrap.jar https://dhh.dobrovolskyi.xyz/pack.toml\n&#96;&#96;&#96;\n\n**Usage in Prism Launcher:**\n1. Copy &#96;client/&#96; folder to your instance's &#96;.minecraft/&#96;\n2. Make executable: &#96;chmod +x update.sh&#96;\n3. Set Pre-launch command: &#96;\"$INST_MC_DIR/client/update.sh\" \"$INST_JAVA\"&#96;\n\n### Modrinth Pack Format\n\nTo export for Modrinth App users:\n\n&#96;&#96;&#96;bash\npackwiz modrinth export\n&#96;&#96;&#96;\n\nThis creates a &#96;.mrpack&#96; file that can be imported directly.\n\n### CurseForge Format\n\nFor CurseForge App users:\n\n&#96;&#96;&#96;bash\npackwiz curseforge export\n&#96;&#96;&#96;\n\n### Manual Update (Any Launcher)\n\n1. Download [packwiz-installer-bootstrap.jar](https://github.com/packwiz/packwiz-installer-bootstrap/releases)\n2. Place in your &#96;.minecraft/&#96; folder\n3. Run before launching:\n   &#96;&#96;&#96;bash",

        "contents": "## Hosting the Pack\n\n### GitHub Pages\n\n1. Push pack to GitHub repository\n2. Enable GitHub Pages (Settings → Pages → main branch)\n3. Pack URL: &#96;https://username.github.io/repo/pack.toml&#96;\n\n### Self-Hosted\n\nServe files via any HTTP server:\n\n&#96;&#96;&#96;bash\n# Development server (packwiz built-in)\npackwiz serve\n\n# Production (nginx, Caddy, etc.)\n# Just serve the directory as static files\n&#96;&#96;&#96;\n\n## Git Workflow\n\n### .gitignore\n\n&#96;&#96;&#96;gitignore\n# Ignore downloaded JARs\nmods/*.jar\nshaderpacks/*.zip\n\n# Keep metadata\n!mods/*.pw.toml\n!shaderpacks/*.toml\n&#96;&#96;&#96;\n\n### Committing Changes\n\n1. Make changes (add/remove/update mods)\n2. Run &#96;packwiz refresh&#96;\n3. Commit both &#96;.pw.toml&#96; files and &#96;index.toml&#96;\n\n## Troubleshooting\n\n### \"Hash mismatch\" errors\n\nRe-run &#96;packwiz refresh&#96; to update hashes.\n\n### Mod not found on Modrinth\n\n1. Check if mod exists for your Minecraft version\n2. Use &#96;packwiz url add&#96; for direct downloads\n3. Check mod loader compatibility (Fabric vs NeoForge)\n\n### Fabric mods on NeoForge\n\nThis pack uses Sinytra Connector. For Fabric-only mods:\n\n1. Add the mod normally via &#96;packwiz modrinth install&#96;\n2. Connector will handle compatibility at runtime\n3. Some mods may need &#96;loader = \"fabric\"&#96; in their &#96;.pw.toml&#96;\n\n## Testing Changes\n\n### Local Testing\n\n1. Run &#96;packwiz serve&#96; in the pack directory\n2. Configure launcher to use &#96;http://localhost:8080/pack.toml&#96;\n3. Launch game and verify changes\n\n### Validation\n\n&#96;&#96;&#96;bash\n# Check for issues\npackwiz refresh\n\n# Verify all mods can be downloaded\npackwiz refresh --check\n&#96;&#96;&#96;\n\n## Server Deployment System\n\nThe server uses a custom Python deployment script instead of &#96;packwiz-installer&#96; for better control over side-exclusivity.\n\n### deploy_modpack.py\n\nLocated at &#96;~/games/servers/dhh-server/deploy_modpack.py&#96;, this script:\n\n1. **Parses** the remote &#96;pack.toml&#96; and &#96;index.toml&#96;\n2. **Filters** mods by &#96;side&#96; property (skips &#96;side = \"client\"&#96;)\n3. **Downloads** only server-compatible mods\n4. **Cleans** stale JARs not in the current index\n\n&#96;&#96;&#96;python\n# Key features:\n# - Respects side = \"client\" | \"server\" | \"both\"\n# - Hash verification for cached downloads",

            "line": 137

        },
        "contents": "### Q: Maps not saving / resetting\n\n**A:** Xaero's maps are stored per-server. If the server IP/name changes, maps may appear reset. Check &#96;.minecraft/XaeroWorldMap&#96; for saved data.\n\n## Server Issues\n\n### Q: Server won't start\n\n**A:** Common causes:\n1. EULA not accepted - create &#96;eula.txt&#96; with &#96;eula=true&#96;\n2. Wrong Java version - requires Java 21+\n3. Port already in use - check if another process uses port 25565\n4. Not enough RAM - allocate at least 4GB\n\n### Q: Players can't connect\n\n**A:** Check:\n1. Server is running and shows \"Done\" in console\n2. Firewall allows port 25565 TCP\n3. If behind NAT, port forwarding is configured\n4. &#96;server-ip=&#96; in server.properties is empty or correct\n\n### Q: Lag when players explore\n\n**A:** Pre-generate chunks:\n&#96;&#96;&#96;\n/chunky radius 5000\n/chunky start\n&#96;&#96;&#96;\nThis prevents on-the-fly chunk generation lag.\n\n### Q: How to whitelist players?\n\n**A:** \n&#96;&#96;&#96;\n/whitelist on\n/whitelist add PlayerName\n&#96;&#96;&#96;\n\n## Mod-Specific Questions\n\n### Q: How do I use JEI?\n\n**A:** Press R on an item to see recipes, U to see uses. Type in the search bar to filter items.\n\n### Q: How do I set up a waystone?\n\n**A:** Craft a waystone and place it. Right-click to name it. Other waystones you discover are automatically linked.\n\n### Q: How do I create a backpack?\n\n**A:** Craft a Traveler's Backpack using leather and a chest. Equip it in the chest slot or back slot.\n\n### Q: How do I use Distant Horizons?\n\n**A:** It works automatically, rendering low-detail terrain beyond your normal render distance. Configure in Options → DH Settings.\n\n## Updating\n\n### Q: How do I update the modpack?\n\n**A:** If using packwiz-installer, just launch the game - it updates automatically. For manual installs, re-download all mods.\n\n### Q: Will updating break my world?\n\n**A:** Generally no. Mod updates are usually save-compatible. Always backup your world before major updates.\n\n### Q: How do I know what version I'm on?\n\n**A:** Check &#96;pack.toml&#96; for the version number, or look at the window title in-game.\n\n## Getting Help\n\nIf your issue isn't listed here:",

        "contents": "# AGENTS.md\n\nInstructions for AI coding assistants working with this repository.\n\n## Project Overview\n\nThis is a **Minecraft modpack** managed with [packwiz](https://packwiz.infra.link/). The pack runs on **NeoForge 1.21.11** and uses **Sinytra Connector** for Fabric mod compatibility.\n\n## Key Files\n\n| File | Purpose |\n|------|---------|\n| &#96;pack.toml&#96; | Main pack configuration (name, version, Minecraft/loader versions) |\n| &#96;index.toml&#96; | Auto-generated file index with SHA256 hashes |\n| &#96;mods/*.pw.toml&#96; | Metadata files for each mod (NOT the actual JARs) |\n| &#96;docs/&#96; | Documentation (included in pack distribution) |\n\n## Important Concepts\n\n### Packwiz Metadata Format\n\nMods are NOT stored as JAR files. Instead, each mod has a &#96;.pw.toml&#96; metadata file:\n\n&#96;&#96;&#96;toml\nname = \"Mod Name\"\nfilename = \"modfile.jar\"\nside = \"both\"  # client, server, or both\n\n[download]\nurl = \"https://cdn.modrinth.com/...\"\nhash-format = \"sha512\"\nhash = \"...\"\n\n[update]\n[update.modrinth]\nmod-id = \"XXXXXXXX\"\nversion = \"abc123\"\n&#96;&#96;&#96;\n\n### Index File\n\n&#96;index.toml&#96; is auto-generated and tracks all files with their hashes. **Never edit manually** - run &#96;packwiz refresh&#96; instead.\n\n## Common Tasks\n\n### Adding a Mod\n\n&#96;&#96;&#96;bash\n# From Modrinth (preferred)\npackwiz modrinth install &lt;mod-name&gt;\n\n# From CurseForge\npackwiz curseforge install &lt;mod-name&gt;\n&#96;&#96;&#96;\n\n### Removing a Mod\n\n&#96;&#96;&#96;bash\npackwiz remove &lt;mod-name&gt;\n&#96;&#96;&#96;\n\n### Updating Mods\n\n&#96;&#96;&#96;bash\n# Single mod\npackwiz update &lt;mod-name&gt;\n\n# All mods\npackwiz update --all\n&#96;&#96;&#96;\n\n### After Manual Edits\n\nAlways run after editing any files:\n&#96;&#96;&#96;bash\npackwiz refresh\n&#96;&#96;&#96;\n\n## Do's and Don'ts\n\n### ✅ DO\n\n- Run &#96;packwiz refresh&#96; after any manual file changes\n- Use &#96;packwiz modrinth install&#96; for adding mods\n- Check mod compatibility with NeoForge 1.21.11\n- Keep documentation in &#96;/docs&#96; updated\n- Use &#96;side = \"client\"&#96; for client-only mods, &#96;side = \"server\"&#96; for server-only\n\n### ❌ DON'T\n\n- Never manually edit &#96;index.toml&#96; - it's auto-generated\n- Don't commit &#96;.jar&#96; files (they're in &#96;.gitignore&#96;)\n- Don't change &#96;hash&#96; values manually - use &#96;packwiz refresh&#96;",

Recommended backup strategy:\n\n&#96;&#96;&#96;bash\n#!/bin/bash\n# backup.sh\nWORLD_DIR=\"/path/to/server/world\"\nBACKUP_DIR=\"/path/to/backups\"\nDATE=$(date +%Y-%m-%d_%H-%M)\n\ntar -czf \"$BACKUP_DIR/world_$DATE.tar.gz\" \"$WORLD_DIR\"\n\n# Keep only last 7 daily backups\nfind \"$BACKUP_DIR\" -name \"world_*.tar.gz\" -mtime +7 -delete\n&#96;&#96;&#96;\n\nRun via cron:\n&#96;&#96;&#96;bash\n0 4 * * * /path/to/backup.sh\n&#96;&#96;&#96;\n\n## Updating the Pack\n\n&#96;&#96;&#96;bash\n# Stop server first!\njava -jar packwiz-installer-bootstrap.jar -s server https://YOUR_PACK_URL/pack.toml\n&#96;&#96;&#96;\n\nThis will download new mods and remove obsolete ones.",

---


Reviewing the docs, some listed as "both" may be client-only. Checking specific mods that often should be client-only:


---

<tool-use data-tool-type="search" data-tool-name="web_search">
<details>
            <summary>Tool use: **web_search** • Searched web `undefined` • **1** results</summary>
        
| Title | URL | Chunk |
|-------|-----|-------|
| Web Search Results |  | Here’s a breakdown of the “client-only” vs “both-side” settings in Packwiz modpacks—what they *mean*, when to use each, and what to watch out for.<br/><br/>---<br/><br/>## What does “side” mean in Packwiz?<br/><br/>Packwiz lets you tag each mod file with a `side` property in its `.pw.toml` metadata. The possible values are:<br/><br/>- `client` — install only on the client side (player’s game).  <br/>- `server` — install only on dedicated servers.  <br/>- `both` — install in every environment (single-player “integrated server,” dedicated server, client).  <br/>([packwiz.infra.link](https://packwiz.infra.link/reference/pack-format/mod-toml/?utm_source=openai))<br/><br/>This “side” setting controls where the mod gets installed (or included) when the pack is used locally or on a server. It helps reduce unnecessary files being installed and avoids conflicts where a mod tries to run where it shouldn’t.<br/><br/>---<br/><br/>## When to use `client`, `server`, or `both`<br/><br/>\| Use case \| Use `client` \| Use `server` \| Use `both` \|<br/>\|---\|---\|---\|---\|<br/>\| Mod is for visuals/UI/cosmetics only \| Yes \| No \| Yes (if you want it everywhere) \|<br/>\| Mod provides server-side logic (like world gen, gameplay, commands) \| No \| Yes \| Yes \|<br/>\| Single-player only modpacks \| Many should be `client`, but `both` works too \| Rare \| Common \|<br/>\| Multiplayer with dedicated server \| Client machine installs `client` & `both`; server machine installs `server` & `both` \| Only server \| Both is typical for mods needed everywhere \|<br/><br/>---<br/><br/>## What “Both side” really means<br/><br/>- A mod marked `both` will be installed **on client and server**.<br/>- For dedicated servers, having mods that are client-only or unnecessary can lead to **wasted space** or even **bugs/crashes** if mod dependencies are mismatched.  <br/>([docker-minecraft-server.readthedocs.io](https://docker-minecraft-server.readthedocs.io/en/latest/mods-and-plugins/packwiz/?utm_source=openai))<br/>- Mods that are both might include shared code or core functionality required by both sides.  <br/>([packwiz.infra.link](https://packwiz.infra.link/reference/pack-format/mod-toml/?utm_source=openai))<br/><br/>---<br/><br/>## Use cases: “Client only” vs “Both side”<br/><br/>- **Client-only**:  <br/>  Good when mods affect graphics, UI, rendering, shaders, minimaps, etc. These often don’t run correctly (or needlessly) on servers. For example, a mod like “Xaero’s Minimap” should be `client`.  <br/><br/>- **Both side**:  <br/>  Needed if a mod adds core content that's used in both playing and running the server—e.g. mods that add blocks/items you can use on both server and client, or ones that need to be synced (data, networking). Also good if the pack supports single-player or integrated servers.<br/><br/>---<br/><br/>## Specifics with Packwiz export & builders<br/><br/>- When exporting for **Modrinth**, Packwiz *does* support side-specific mods (`client`, `server`, `both`) and will retain side information in the `.mrpack`. The launcher will filter out irrelevant mods depending on where it's running.  <br/>([packwiz.infra.link](https://packwiz.infra.link/tutorials/hosting/modrinth/?utm_source=openai))<br/><br/>- When exporting for **CurseForge**, by default it assumes a **client pack** and includes mods with side `client` or `both`, but *not* pure server-only mods (unless you explicitly use flags to include them). CurseForge’s format doesn’t have strong built-in support for differential client/server bundles.  <br/>([packwiz.infra.link](https://packwiz.infra.link/tutorials/hosting/curseforge/?utm_source=openai))<br/><br/>- Also: when using Packwiz installer on servers (e.g. via a Docker container or headless/install scripts), you can request only server-side mods (including those marked `both`) to be installed with flags. This avoids pulling down client-only stuff you don’t need.  <br/>([docker-minecraft-server.readthedocs.io](https://docker-minecraft-server.readthedocs.io/en/latest/mods-and-plugins/packwiz/?utm_source=openai))<br/><br/>---<br/><br/>## Best practices<br/><br/>1. **Tag mods correctly**: If a mod only affects the client, mark `client`. If it’s required on the server (like world-gen or synchronization), use `server` or `both`.<br/>2. **Avoid client-only mods on servers**: They might break startup or waste resources.<br/>3. **Use `both` only when necessary**: If a mod truly needs to operate on both sides.<br/>4. **Test both environments**: Single-player/integrated server vs dedicated server—to ensure functionality and to verify unwanted mods aren’t included.<br/>5. **Use installer/export flags** when distributing: Users or server operators can choose which side(s) to install.  <br/><br/>---<br/><br/>## TL;DR<br/><br/>- **Client-only** is for things the player sees/uses locally (UI, graphics, etc.).<br/>- **Both-side** is for shared functionality or when the server and client both need it.<br/>- Use `both` only when necessary.<br/>- Proper “side” tags mean cleaner, more efficient packs.<br/>- Exports and installers often provide flags to include only the relevant sides.<br/><br/>---<br/><br/>If you want, I can walk you through how to configure a .pw.toml for a mixed pack (client + server mods) and how to export for both CurseForge and Modrinth correctly—do you want me to do that? |

</details>
</tool-use>

Creating a script to analyze all mods and flag likely client-only ones that are marked "both":


---

<tool-use data-tool-type="shell" data-tool-name="run_terminal_command_v2">
<details><summary>Tool use: **run_terminal_command_v2** • Run command: cd /home/thathunky/games/modpacks/dhh/mods && for f in *.pw.toml; do name=$(grep '^name =' "$f" | head -1 | sed 's/name = "\(.*\)"/\1/'); side=$(grep '^side =' "$f" | head -1 | sed 's/side = "\(.*\)"/\1/'); echo "$side|$name"; done | sort</summary>

```bash
cd /home/thathunky/games/modpacks/dhh/mods && for f in *.pw.toml; do name=$(grep '^name =' "$f" | head -1 | sed 's/name = "\(.*\)"/\1/'); side=$(grep '^side =' "$f" | head -1 | sed 's/side = "\(.*\)"/\1/'); echo "$side|$name"; done | sort
```
